text: Concrete example from yesterday:  Trying to help the maintainer of package `GSE` I see that even though I have quite a few packages installed, one i.e. `cellWise` was still missing.  So after `install2.r -l /tmp/r/lib cellWise` I was then able to install / check / ... `GSE`, starting from just `install2.r -l /tmp/r/lib GSE` no longer complaining about missing `cellWise`.  I use the same approach for all my reverse dependency check on an old and feeble machine I get to use, there I have a `R_LIBS_USER` pointing a large support directory with all the various dependencies.

text:
Ok (and this may be a case of me holding the tool wrong) ...

• Git clone a development version of someones package. Let's assume there is nothing fancy about this development version (i.e it's DESCRIPTION has dependencies that *are* *on CRAN*).
• Assume that I *do not* have any of the 'Import' dependencies installed.
To use `install.packages()`  on a *local* source package you need to specify `repos = NULL` .  If you do this with unfilled dependency requirements, it will Error.

Gabe's linked <https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=17996|issue>  raised the possibility of a 'local' argument being added to `install.packages()` which would allow you to install a local package without setting repos to NULL and thus be able to download dependencies automagically. Without me giving too much thought, it seemed like something that was a 'relatively' easy win so I was pondering if it had come up at one of the R development days and if there were some blockers that had maybe been discussed.
